Although the role of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in T cell costimulation is firmly established , the mechanisms by which it exerts its costimulatory actions are less clear .

In many circumstances it is difficult to distinguish the effects of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from subsequent actions of cytokines , such as <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , on T cell proliferation .

Here , we report a model of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation using PMA plus the natural ligand <extra_id_0> CD80 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that resulted in very limited stimulation of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as evidenced by both cytokine production and <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter stimulation .

text: In addition , T cell proliferation was completely resistant to the actions of the immunosuppressant cyclosporin A ( CsA ) .

Moreover T cell proliferation was unaffected by the addition of blocking Abs to both <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the IL-2 receptor , demonstrating that this form of costimulation by <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was independent of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

We also investigated the effects of stimulating T cell blasts with <extra_id_0> CD80 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone and found that there was a limited requirement for <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in this system .

We conclude that <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation can cause substantial T cell proliferation in the absence of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which is driven by a soluble factor independent of NF-AT transactivation .
